personnel but for the management staff as well so it's obvious that resistance
at that point where a decision needs to be made is natural so you have a choice
moving forward with a cloud adoption strategy means that you have to consider
the the organization that you're bringing with you part of that one of the choices is well
I just hire a whole new group of people there's a lot of smart people coming at a university with all kinds of
development skills and their cloud already already I could do that that's one method another way and you'll note
from my three orange bullets there is the one we prefer this to train your
existing organization there there's a large group of people that have a
significant amount of intellectual property in the way your business runs you cannot dismiss that you have to keep
it and and look for means by which you can move these and train these existing
staff first and foremost it's less expensive certainly a hook it hecka have a lot more scalable and it's much faster
as well but training your staff is only really the tip of the iceberg there's a
lot more to take into consideration there and a holistic approach that involves understanding the human
motivation for this adoption change is key and there's three three main
dimensions to that that we're looking at one is to create an environment where you're offering a sense of empowerment
and autonomy for your teams that's keenly important another one in which
you're giving them the opportunity to become masterful at what they do this is new it's new to most of us and our staff
and our employees are gonna be looking at this adoption how can you get them to a point where they feel that they can master this environment certainly helps
in the in driving their motivation and the last dimension of that is purpose
you must help them be aligned with the reason why we're doing this in the
first place so whatever that reason is if there's a visionary direction to your
organization the the Treasury Board Secretariat of Canada has put forward a cloud first strategy that's part of
creating a vision in a direction that now needs to be translated down into more specific to the organization why
are we doing this and why am i involved and that's really beyond just the training is looking at that part so I'm
gonna go through a 12 step process to help accommodate this change but for the
sake of time because we've only got about 45 minutes 50 minutes together I'm gonna make it a 9-step process so the
first one is looking at accept acceptance we have to help our teams get
to a point where there's an acceptance to what's under way and what's going on because this is going to happen this
roller coaster ride that you're gonna go on has started and the concerns and the
emotional roller coaster of your staff are gonna hit you hard if they haven't already so it's happening and the way I
want to depict this is to look at something called the kubler-ross acceptance curve has anybody familiar
with the kubler-ross acceptance curve fantastic so it's really a curve that
demonstrates morale and performance when large in an organizational sense that is
when a large transformational change is brought forward the first thing that
happens is denial right now this is never going to happen to us this cloud
thing is just a fad it's going to pass us by we're gonna continue doing this
virtualization thing that we took at the last 10 years to get here that's what I'm gonna keep doing so there's a denial
that happens naturally and the strategy which is what I've depicted here on the on the right-hand side of the slide is
what we need to do as leaders and managers of this data is to look at
different strategies that we can put in place so the strategy to a deal with denial is find ways to create alignment
so how you go about doing that well again will be different to your organization
but typically it means oh the French folks got the advance look at what's
going on over there you're lucky you guys are still in the
dark over here so don't don't look over there yet we've got creating alignment
as the strategy so how you do that is through you know team meetings and letting people know what the vision is
and why we're doing this what's the the pros and cons and mainly the pros as to the the change is being given the second
dimension the second dimension is frustration that'll come naturally after denial and they're really there the
strategy is to over communicate coffee talks team meetings town halls whatever
that might be and then when depression kicks in which is natural it's like oh
god I'm gonna have to do it anyway and when that depression kicks in the strategy is to drive towards better
acceptance is to spark motivation and look for means to incent your team
members to move forward and part of the way of sparking motivation is to experiment get the new technology in
your hands start the experimentation process and start developing capacity give them the experience they need that
proves the vision that you created for them at the beginning and it's only at that point in time after there's been
some demonstratable means by which you've shown value and proven that
there's an alignment between what we're doing in the direction that we're heading organizationally that acceptance starts to happen and the best thing to
do at that time strategically is to start sharing that knowledge letting everybody know what you've done how
you've done it and so on part of the reason why we're having summits of this
nature with our client base and we do these globally and for those of you who don't know there is a global public
sector summit that occurs every June in Washington DC so I encourage you to
consider that as part of your travel plans and learning opportunities for next year but these summits themselves
are a means by which we can share knowledge with you of other people's successes when they've
finished their experimentation and well let Gio talk to you about what he's succeeded in doing later
step two is training get your folks going to the training this is one
example is the AWS technical essentials class it's a one-day sort of deep dive into some of the foundational
technologies and services that we have to offer so this is this is that slice
there you're seeing with the very fine print is really only just a small subset of the foundational services upon which
all of the other 125 plus cloud services we do sit on top of that but you kind of
need to understand that foundational bit first but this is one way of doing it it gives everyone a broad perspective and
then as people I self-identify towards a particular role or particular task then
you head them down there appropriate training paths the third step is providing people with a safe environment
to do some hands-on experimentation refer to that as part of the strategy to put in place when you're looking to
drive acceptance so the the the quote that we love using in this place is the
one given by our CEO which is there is no compression algorithm for experience you know we can bring you some of the
intellectual properties and learnings that we've had with other clients but your own personal experience has to come
from actually doing something and that really means in the cloud environment
there's a very easy way to create safe enclaves where you can go out launch
services break things and when that happens you just delete them and start
over there really is no collateral damage to experimentation in the cloud
the fourth step and I'll take a little bit of time diving into this one is
organizational creation what do you do with your teams how do we go about doing
this and this is taken from a concept that amazon.com uses I mean it's
creating its services and technology that we deliver to our customers which I
think at least I am I'm an Amazon Prime user if you all are then you you've
you've been the recipient to some of the products that we deliver and how we go
about doing that so how we structure ourselves organizationally is really in very small agile teams we refer to it as two Pizza
teams and the idea from Jeff Bezos is if you can't feed a team with two pizzas then your team's too big get it smaller
small agile teams and bring in bring in the appropriate expertise there so I'll dive into that a little bit more and I
did my best to use a diagram that makes the team look like a pizza they see
everybody there is basically a small pepperoni slice on them on the larger pizza the first leader to the product
teams and they said the two pizza team is the product manager they're really sort of the all-knowing Swiss Army knife
of the environment you're going to build the product you're going to release and how to go about building it they
initially take on all of the appropriate functions and requirements of the of that team including business and
development and they prioritize where the workload is going to go based on the
the particular customer feedback and that is the the gentleman who is really
going to be supporting your first mover clients so if there's an application
that's the first mover I mentioned earlier there's some of those our cloud native others are legacy migration
whatever that first mover is that's the the general the the the team lead that's going to be taking that on and if the
product manager is masterful at doing things on the white board the lead
architect is the one who is masterful at doing things on the keyboard so you have
one person who can translate business requirements into technology requirements on the white board and the other person is actually putting into
practice and this this list lead architect is accountable for the overall cloud architecture works with the product
manager to drive out these technical deliverables establishes a direction and
the full delivery of that new product and they're supported by four other
smaller teams smaller individuals pardon me they're not smaller
individuals there's focused individuals in the in the to Pizza team more
particularly the infrastructure engineers these are the ones that today
are dealing in your on-prem environments and get really jazzed and excited every
time there's a new acquisition that happens which probably happens a couple of times a year they're the ones who
when a when an RFP gets awarded the Box gets shipped and they think it's
Christmas day when they get to open the box rack and stack that machine and plug it in and they get very excited about
that so that same group are the ones that now are going to be transported and
embedded into this - pizza team and they become the ones that now no longer have
to do any of that undifferentiated heavy lifting of boxes and machines so the
question is how do they get motivated then and this is really one of the means by doing it is embedding them into this
product development team where they have an outcome driven day where they spend
their time focused on delivering a product whereas before they were opening boxes and delivering a server now
they're embedded and part of the delivery of an actual product or program that's going to be consumed by either
internal internal customer or by a citizen the other thing that we do is we
embed the security team right into that - pizza team it's no longer a situation
in which you get your product developed and done and at the tail end of it all you hand it over the security team for a
threat and risk analysis only to be told no you've forgotten to do something important when it comes to
your security and governance now we're embedding that team right into the product development team they're part of
that cycle and they're the ones who will be then providing that standardized
offering ensuring that ongoing security is embedded into all areas of the
process including the infrastructure the application the data and so on the other
two members of the team are the operations engineers you still need to operate the environment this is part of
the shared responsibility model in the cloud we as Amazon will be responsible
for protecting and securing and managing the cloud you still remain responsible
for managing what you choose to put in the cloud including the infrastructure that you're going to be launching so
those operations engineers need to be part of the team to build the process that's required and automate that
process to ensure that that environment remains operational on an ongoing basis and they do that by driving code and
automation into that but they continue to deal with Health metrics logging
alerting inventory and so on and last
but not least and this is probably the most important part of the to be a team is taking the application owners and the
program owners or to representatives of that application owner program owner and
embedding them in the team as well they're the ones that are going to be representing the application requirements and again it's they are the
ones who will be that the the product manager and the lead engineer lead architect will be going to and asking
for those business requirements reviewing the work that they're doing with them on an ongoing basis and
typically once this team is fully formed the delivery of a product program or
application that they're delivering should take no more than 12 weeks and if it takes more than that then once again
you've probably got a team that's too big so all in all
look at two Pizza teams as being a team of eight to ten people made up of these general roles and that is how we achieve
speed agility and and also drive the the
an outcome based approach so the other key point there and you'll see the last bullet is that this is really a virtual

for that I don't know how to make it switch but I'm pretty sure someone smarter than you'll figure it out in just a moment
also my confidence monitor is not working - so one of the things is
understanding that in Canada today when you think about the Canada Pension Plan yes it's the fun by which we manage our
pensions but as well when you look at the performance that the fund has been doing over the last couple of years and
specifically if you look at the fiscal end of March 2018 357 billion assets
under management 11.6 percent growth year over year so we can really see that the fund is performing really well the
investors and the asset management portfolio and the portfolio managers are doing a really good job at looking at
the global economy looking at the global vapors from all of the massive datasets
that are being generated by both private and public equities and being able to understand how do we make a an
active investment long-term always making sure that there's that viability
within our fund and so one of the things that the fund wanted to do is to look at
how the investors and the asset managers within the portfolio and the individual
portfolios were using technology so if you talk to the thematic investors these
are the guys that write the quants there are very statistical in nature they're very good at algorithms and you'll find
that in in their personas they're very capable technically speaking they can
sit down they can write Python they can write R they can write Scala they all write their algorithms they'll deploy their own containers they'll also go and
sign up in a virtual machine somewhere and write everything that they need to come and answer a very specific question
is a clean code is a good code well that's not the important part they're answering a question question is is this
investment a good one for Canadians and as they do this work they're doing it
each with their own lens and so the senior management leadership team at the CBI be said well if we're going to have
aspirations to grow the fund to one trillion of assets under management over
the next 15 25 years what are the things that we have to do as an organization to
enable cross synergy thinking how do we allow the really good work that's happening in each of the different data
silos or the digital silos within the organization to expand outside of itself and share whether its products that
they've built for themselves such as data services that some of these investors build for themselves or other
third party or first party information that's created or acquired within our internal systems and so for our 2025
vision the senior leader management team alongside with its board decided that it
was time to adopt cloud technology ine corporate-wide mandate and so that meant that new
capabilities would drive new insights which would give us more opportunity to leverage our investments across the
globe and as well take a Cure lis commercial advantage of the market by
being able to see things that other people may have not caught on to just yet giving us the opportunity to become
alphas in the investment spaces that were working with as you can imagine this is a quite
ambitious mandate and so to start where do you start when if every time you go
into a room you get the well it's working we're doing pretty good I'm already writing my own code I don't need
anything further from you it becomes a bit of a challenge I don't know if this thing is working or if you need to
change my slide I apologize for the technical issues so what we sat down to
look at was how do we create a cross-functional conversation beyond technology because if you start to talk
about technology well then everybody has their own opinions and everyone's going to have the best-in-class of way of doing things and of course from a
technologists point of view or an operator's point of view you end up with some type of technical debt it's
inevitable you're going to have people using a plethora of tools you're gonna have people using a plethora of
approaches and then reconciling them in a thoughtful and provocative way so that ensures stability and growth around the
information security and the governance and the compliancy it creates a little bit of a complex challenge over time so
one of the first things that was done was to sit down with all of our senior leaders and our management teams within
the CPI be and understand really not just from a technology and data strategy but also from a cloud adoption strategy
how do we look at the three three the three themes that plagues all of us in
this space people processes and then the technologies themselves well if we
always start a technology because it's the easiest conversation to have we end up with da Matic almost semi-religious
views on technology this time is better than not tech this API from this service
is a whole lot better than this one and really it's very hard to move away from that discussion so we created a little
bit of a framework to talk about how we want a technology to enable our
investors and then what was the practice around the usage of the technology so we really started at the use cases so what
is it that we would want to do individually in each of our portfolios but then how do we expose those things
where appropriately we're within compliance and regulatory were allowed to do so a
across the fund so that others can consume it and continue to further refine it or add it to a strategy for
investment and so we came up with our foundational components and the one that we really started first with was well
what is the data that people are using what are the digital assets that they've created for themselves because if you go
into some of the quant investing teams and they have these magic servers that just pop out of nowhere where they've
written a whole lot of code and in some cases is pretty elegant stuff as they're writing their algorithms and now how do
you take that and expose it across wide well bringing it to the cloud may not be so easy as you have to kind of decompose
a little bit of what was done monolithically not to be able to expose it as services that others can consume
so we decided with a data marketplace let's start to define what are the data sets and the technologies within those
data sets that are being used across the fun let's document them let's have a place where people can go and see and
read and maybe that data set is not available because it just exists for the real asset portfolio managers but the
fact that they know now that it's available it's starting to spur new conversations within the organization where people are asking hey can I get my
hands on that that looks pretty interesting I really want that or you guys acquired this third-party data from this open data set
it seems really interesting I'd like to get the exhaust or the vapor from it I want to understand how many IOT sensors
are out of there I want to see how many people are parking their cars in the shopping malls now they sound like
benign questions but if you're thinking strategically on how to invest any signal you can get from the market that
others are not looking at gives you that competitive edge and so that's what the teams are looking at the other thing too
was the architecture needed to be scalable so this is processes how do you change the conversation around while
today things may reside in the cloud serve and you may have a monolithic application that's serving them tomorrow
it's just an API you're going to call bring your own tool so for some this is breath of fresh air ideas not in the way
you're not stopping me and for others it's kind of scary because I've been using this desktop tool for ever and
it's been working really great now you're asking me to learn what I have to do what I have to call you to do every time I want to do something I can do
right now so is breaking down those barriers in having those discussions one that worked really well for us in this
data marketplace and in the architecture discussion was taking our technologists who understood investing although they
call themselves armchair investors we don't let them invest we have professionals for that but getting them to talk in business terms and investment
terms with their stakeholders so we actually embedded them in some of those in some of those conversations some of
them had the Dilbert moment where they came back and says I just want to work on the server I don't want to go back others have appreciated that because
they said now I really understand the pain that they're going through so when we're making decisions on tool sets it's
not so much operationally what's easy for us but also what meets their needs but is something that they really can
use an adoptee and so when we went back they'll talk about how things would now
move to the cloud specifically AWS the conversation wasn't so contentious in where you were disrupting me and you
were taking away my precious time to generate revenue for the fun - you're
actually going to help me make more for the fun you're actually going to help me increase and reach our corporate mandate
so let's talk a little bit more how we can scale things once they were able to break down those conversational barriers
then the technology part was a little easier because now once you understood what skill set you understood what kind
